html:
My way is like git reset HEAD~x --hard where x is no.of commits after the last conference (i.e PyCon).
Then i will use git tag -a PyDelhiConf_2016 -m "Changes for PyDelhi Conference March 5, 2016 start from here." for marking of beginning of work for PyDelhiConf
Though i think reset --hard part can be bad (it works on my machine), in terms of bad-use?
text:
My way is like `git reset HEAD~x --hard` where x is no.of commits after the last conference (i.e PyCon).
Then i will use `git tag -a PyDelhiConf_2016 -m "Changes for PyDelhi Conference March 5, 2016 start from here."` for marking of beginning of work for PyDelhiConf
Though i think reset --hard part can be bad (it works on my machine), in terms of bad-use?

html:
Then we are done making changes for PydelhiConf_2016 we can use similarly the tagging
git tag -a PyDelhiConf_2016_ends -m "Changes for PyDelhi Conference ends here'.
text:
Then we are done making changes for `PydelhiConf_2016` we can use similarly the tagging
`git tag -a PyDelhiConf_2016_ends -m "Changes for PyDelhi Conference ends here'`.

html: why use reset? You can do the same thing with git checkout
text: why use reset? You can do the same thing with `git checkout`

text: Ok, i will do that then. Though I just it to be an unoptimised way of doing. Since `git` already serves the purpose of keeping a history of changes and we can visit the past (you already :) that i know), unoptimized in the way that, it will increase the size of contents.

html: It could either serve as an archive of past presentations, without checking out to a past commit in history, or otherwise we can remove previous material when we are done creating the PyDelhiConf Material and in the next conference, we can simply improve PyDelhiConf Material & rename it.
text: It could either serve as an archive of past presentations, without checking out to a past commit in history, or otherwise we can remove previous material when we are done creating the `PyDelhiConf Material` and in the next conference, we can simply improve  `PyDelhiConf Material` & rename it.

text: git will automatically store duplicate contents efficiently. You should do things in the way that make the most practical sense

html: How can i add a tag to the repo (using git tag -a), just "after the commit" of October 2, 2015, i am referring to https://github.com/aktech/sympy-tutorial/commits/master as branch.
text: How can i add a `tag` to the repo (using `git tag -a`), just "after the commit" of `October 2, 2015`, i am referring to https://github.com/aktech/sympy-tutorial/commits/master  as branch.

html: The most intuitive way to tag is probably through the github release interface.
text: The most intuitive way to tag is probably through the github release interface.

html: Or git tag PyDelhi
text: Or `git tag PyDelhi`

html: through command line
text: through command line

text: For web interface see this: https://github.com/aktech/sympy-tutorial/tags

html: It's just a few clicks from the Web interface, by clicking on the release.

html: If you want to do it with command line then you can checkout to a past commit in history, and then tag it.
text: If you want to do it with command line then you can `checkout` to a past commit in history, and then `tag` it.
